{

      "evidence": "Let’s talk about why we have this factor of one over capital N in the inverse discrete Fourier transform."

      "s": "1/N",
      "p": "equals",

      "s": "original continuous function",

      "o": "collection of rectangles",
      "modalities": ["text"],
      "confidence": 1.0,
      "evidence": "Think of it this way: when we move from the continuous Fourier transform to the discrete version, we’re replacing continuous integrals with sums. In the time domain, we can picture our original continuous function as being approximated by a collection of rectangles."

evidence: Think of it this way: when we move from the continuous Fourier transform to the discrete version, we’re replacing continuous integrals with sums. In the time domain, we can picture our original continuous function as being approximated by a collection of rectangles.
